body: Agreed. I had my own version, but I should be able to build on top of this for other non EMR related operators
i can do a follow-up that allows for templating via introspection if that sounds good to you guys
Sounds good to me. @artwr ?
According to @artwr this failure is expected, so I view the failed tests as non-block. The failure should go away tomorrow.

It looks like this commit added a flaky test:

  File "/home/travis/build/apache/incubator-airflow/tests/models.py", line 560, in test_xcom_pull_different_execution_date

Thanks so much for adding tests. Really valuable.

> it might be a good idea to offer another optional parameter for max_retry_delay

+1 This seems useful, and fairly straight forward to add (min(max_retry_delay, delay)).

Overall, PR looks good. Had a minor nit.

In general LGTM, but a manual naming is not recommended, see https://media.readthedocs.org/pdf/alembic/latest/alembic.pdf chapter 5. So we might want to 'upgrade' our standard here to make it more future proof. For your consideration, I'm fine with merging it now.
+1, I would like to a have a bit more descriptive commit message
LGTM, too, but one nit
That makes sense to me, we should move all of our indexes.

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-303

@jlowin, @criccomini, @bolkedebruin, @r39132

hey guys, sorry I'm a bit late here, but would it actually be possible to make some sort of range function for this? for example, here is a monkey patch that I made to my local version of the code to address this problem:

``` python
class TimeRangeExternalTaskSensor(ExternalTaskSensor):
    """
    Monkey patch ExternalTaskSensor to enable fuzzy date searching; this is a hack
    :param execution_date_tolerance_before: how long before the target execution time to search for a task, in seconds
    :type execution_date_tolerance_before: int
    :param execution_date_tolerance_after: how long after the target execution time to search for a task, in seconds
    :type execution_date_tolerance_after: int
    """

    def __init__(
            self,
            execution_date_tolerance_before=0,
            execution_date_tolerance_after=0,
            *args, **kwargs):
        super(TimeRangeExternalTaskSensor, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs)
        self.execution_date_tolerance_before = execution_date_tolerance_before
        self.execution_date_tolerance_after = execution_date_tolerance_after

    def poke(self, context):
        if self.execution_delta:
            dttm = context['execution_date'] - self.execution_delta
        else:
            dttm = context['execution_date']

        logging.info(
            'Poking for '
            '{self.external_dag_id}.'
            '{self.external_task_id} on '
            '{dttm} ... '.format(**locals()))
        TI = TaskInstance

        execution_date_lower_bound = dttm - datetime.timedelta(seconds=self.execution_date_tolerance_before)
        execution_date_upper_bound = dttm + datetime.timedelta(seconds=self.execution_date_tolerance_after)
        logging.info('Searching for matching task(s) with execution_date between [{}, {}]...'.format(execution_date_lower_bound, execution_date_upper_bound))

        session = settings.Session()
        count = session.query(TI).filter(
            TI.dag_id == self.external_dag_id,
            TI.task_id == self.external_task_id,
            TI.state.in_(self.allowed_states),
            TI.execution_date >= execution_date_lower_bound,
            TI.execution_date <= execution_date_upper_bound
        ).count()
        session.commit()
        session.close()
        return count
```

One use case I can see is that if the DAGs are being manually triggered via `airflow trigger_dag`, then it will be very hard to programmatically hit the exact datetime that it actually got triggered at, (as it probably won't align with a specific minute at 0 seconds, for instance).

You can see that what I've done here is actually modified the filter to be more flexible in how it queries the underlying database. I see that there is already an index on this 4-arity tuple `dag_id, task_id, execution_date, state`, so since I am staying within the parameters of the queries this index was designed to optimize for, there shouldn't be a major performance hit.

Happy to discuss this further; I would have tried to put together a PR myself but hadn't gotten around to it  due to time constraints and competing priorities :(

@omnilinguist that's a great use case. Your code is more than a monkey patch, that looks like a pretty good `Operator` in and of itself. My gut feeling is that the "range" behavior is different enough from the "point" behavior that it actually does belong in a separate `Operator`, and my suggestion is that you should PR your code to create one! If we combine them into one operator, it will have 4 parameters (quite complex) and it won't be clear from the UI if it's checking a point (current behavior) or range (new behavior) unless someone looks at the actual code.

I was in favor of changing the state in the scheduler instead of the executor so that state changes are more centralized.
Let me update the wiki once we finalize these changes...

To address concerns that timeout won't work on child thread, I've modified the `timeout` class to use `sys.settrace` if it's not on a main thread. I've tested that it times out simple loops and some long-loading airbnb production dags. Disadvantages are that 
1. `settrace`, although part of the public api, is poorly documented
2. it makes loading refreshed dags 2-5x slower (load time on startup is not changed)

Hey everyone.  I'm trying to get airflow working in production, but for some reason the scheduler stops working after a few hours.  I've added some more detailed logging and have tracked the issue back to the `while any(j.is_alive() for j in jobs):` loop introduced in this PR.  For some reason, after running fine for hours, the main process will get stuck in this loop.  I can run `top` on my airflow scheduler container and can see that the child process actually spawns, while the main process is looping endlessly using about 100% CPU.  From what I can tell, the `_do_dags` target function never actually runs when this happens.  Any ideas?
@schnie provide sample dag that exhibits this. Then it will become much easier to track this down. Next to that please create a Jira issue for it and provide as much info as you can

I think a mark success feature is a good one.  I have been looking for one and don't like running a backfill to achieve it. There is one issue I noticed on the current 1.7.1.3 release.

I was 3 days behind on an hourly run. I was hoping a single `backfill -m` would suffice to mark everything success till current. However, since DAG Runs/Task Instances are generated in little groups by scheduler cycles, that was not the case.... I had to continuously run mark success.. for an hour.
@gwax, please follow the **50/72** rule for the commit message. Thanks.
LGTM - thanks @skudriashev!
Looks good now -- the lone Travis failure is obviously unrelated. Thanks!
